symptoms.name: Skin lesions
symptoms.pattern: Acrodermatitis, erosions with moist, erythematous base, perianal moist erythematous lesion, cheilitis, vesiculobullous rash (sometimes called syphilitic pemphigus), maculopapular rash on palms and soles, desquamation, erythema multiforme, papulosquamous lesions, generalized erythematous, targetoid, scaly macules, papules, pustules

symptoms.name: Rhinitis
symptoms.pattern: Bloody and purulent, may be the earliest clinical sign

physical_findings: Erosions with moist, erythematous base in acral distribution
Generalized erythematous, targetoid, scaly macules, papules, pustules
Multiple erosions with a dry, erythematous base and scaling over borders of bilateral palms and soles
Erythematous, bilaterally symmetrical, moist patches over the perianal area
Cheilitis with a moist erosion over the upper lip
Discrete, skin-colored papulosquamous lesions in both palms (mother)

Two–three nontender, firm, shotty, discrete, bilaterally palpable inguinal lymph nodes with overlying skin normal, without any other cutaneous findings such as a healed scar or postinflammatory hypopigmentation over the genitals (father)

lab_values.CBC: Normocytic normochromic anemia (hemoglobin 8.3 g/dL, hematocrit 27.8%), leukocytosis (WBC 20,000/mm3), thrombocytopenia (86,000/µL)
lab_values.Anti-T. pallidum IgG + IgM: Positive (23.83 IU/mL at diagnosis, decreased at 3 months)

risk_factors: Inadequate treatment of maternal syphilis during pregnancy
Contact with infectious lesion during birth

imaging_findings.Ultrasonography: Normal (transfontanel and abdominal), Patent foramen ovale (echocardiography)

required: Positive non-treponemal serologic test (e.g., RPR, VDRL)
supportive: Abnormal laboratory findings (e.g., anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis)
Imaging findings consistent with congenital syphilis
